A thing of beauty indeed!

 
 Black is beautiful! 
 
 I used to love to watch drag racing in my younger days (early 70's) - I used to go the track just about every weekend. I live close to one of the oldest 1/4 mi tracks in the country. (Thorn Hill, Kenton Ky.) Built in about 1950, and still in operation as far as I know. Small and obscure though, then and now. I got tired of going - too crowded, too many grocery-getters. There were some real ground-shakers there in the early seventies! Mid 14's, ooooh pretty quick! Low 12's Wow - out of this world!! haha boring by todays standards!
My project, completed a few years ago.

Not a racer - body work has always been my specialty. That's a conglumeration of 67 - 72 parts. It's titled as a 70, but is largely a 71 model. Came factory with a 360 auto according to the ID plate, but had no engine or trans when I got it. I put a 73 Comet 302 in it, and mated it to a 91 F-150 5 speed manuel OD. A good interstate cruiser, in spite of the low rear end gears that all those old 3/4 ton trucks had.
It's not real fast, so it has to work to earn it's keep. :p

Black is beautiful!

 Thanks! :)
 
 The Chev vs Ford wars were intense back then! I had heard that the owner of Thorn Hill (a farmer) was a die hard Ford man, as was I, but the Chevrolets ruled down there. (never saw the owner around during the races) There just weren't that many Fords around, and the ones that were usually weren't much. No bracket racing back then, all "class" racing. Cars were classified by how they were equipped. "Stock", "modified" "altered" etc. When different classes ran against each other in the final money rounds, there were "spots" (head starts) to equalize them. Almost all 4 speeds, very few automatics. Really something watching them blast off the line - seems like they didn't go 30 feet before they were grabbing second gear - no helmets, those long haired guys of that era haha, their hair would be straight back! I remember one guy kept breaking bolts in his seat mounts! They really laid into those shifts! 
 
 So many Novas, Camaros, Chevelles, and of course, the 55 - 57 Chevs. A few ho-hum Mustangs, but every once in a while a big body Ford would show up that knew what he was doing, and it was quite fun to watch. Once there was a really clean maroon 64 Galaxie, stock looking except for wide slicks, bubble hood and 427 emblems. (no advertising, seldom any advertising anywhere at that track) He only showed up 4 or 5 weekends, but was always right there at the end - won top money once or twice. (it was a mid 11's piece) My best memory was a somewhat faded blue 68 Torino fastback with a 428. Final round, he was up against an almost new Nova, 396 I think. The Ford seemed to bog off the line a little, but really turned on at the top end. The Nova got the head start. I bet a quarter on it with some disgusting high school classmate who was there watching too. Both 4 speeds, that Nova left really strong, it seemed like he was 1/4 of way gone when the ol Ford dug in and took off after him. The Ford barely edged him - I must have gone 3 feet in the air, I was never so happy to grab that quarter from a red faced guy in my life!!!
 
 Memories are a fun part of getting old!

Cars we used to dream about in England !
 Youve lived the dream man!

Cars we used to dream about in England !
 Youve lived the dream man!

 
 Oh, I don't know about that - the grass is always greener on the other side. :) I've missed some things by never seeing England, I do hope to visit someday. Or Australia! They've got some real car nuts down there! 
 
 So much of car racing in the U.S. was born of bootlegging. Thorn Hill was no different. Page down about 2/3 of the way in this link, and read some interesting stuff about Thorn Hill. Ralf Payne was the Ford-man owner I was referring to above. Several years after I lost interest in going there, one of my mechanic friends used to do work on Ralf's farm equipment. Ralf was never shy about calling any hour of the day - my friend's wife referred to him as Ralf Payne-in-the-a$$. I regret never taking the time to tag along with him and meeting Ralf. 
 
 In my quick search finding that link, I also found some other facts about the track - still in full operation, but just a 1/8 mile track now. Opened in 1953. It's hours of operation have been severely restricted by people building/moving in close by, then complaining about the noise. emoticon_rolleyes
 
 I distinctly remember the occasional stopping of the racing action in the early seventies to let a small plane land, just like the above airfield link says. I'll have to dig for more history on that place when I get time, I'm sure it's out there somewhere. Don't know for sure if anyone was ever killed there, but it wouldn't surprise me. I never witnessed it, but I know lots of cars went down the last half of the track on their tops, lots of fights too! emoticon_emb
 
 Sorry to hijack JP, but this thread may not have gone far without it. I'd like to see more drag racing stories, or pics of others personally built rides.

It's a work of art. How long did it take to modify and what's its top speed?
 http://i82.photobucket.com/albums/j262/MikeThePhotoGuy/Heads%20Up%202009/Rockys%20Sept%203rd/TPG_2752copy.jpg

 
 Top speed in the 1/4 should be just shy of 200mph. Of course, we'll need to add a rear wing and other aero goodies before putting it on "kill". My son and I bought the roller (car w/o engine and trans) almost 3 years ago now. Originally, it was going to get a 632" BBC engine w/N2O, but we knew a motor builder that told us that the fastest turbo motor was for sale because the owner was switching to an LSX motor class, so I picked it up instead. My son did the majority of the work, including rewiring the entire car, plumbing the turbo system and intercooler, trans cooler, etc., 
 Our original intent was to build it to run on E85, so we had 8 x 160# injectors in the intake manifold and 8 more in the throttle body. But, upon advice from a couple of top engine builders and tuners, they advised against it. So for now it's a conventional race gas (C16) turbo motor. Later, we'll play with the 16 injectors and convert it to E85. 
 
 
A thing of beauty indeed!

 
 Thanks. We still need to finish painting the hood and doing the bodywork on the rear fenders where it was tubbed.

 Thank you - Ford trucks have always been my life. I was 13 - summer of 68 - when I used a farmers tractor to pull home my first one with a V tow bar, all by myself early one Sunday morning - a 48 F-1. :) When I turned 16 it was ready to go!

Yes, I remember a few years ago your basic description of your 10 second daily driver. You sold it? emoticon_wow Any new projects in the works? 

 
 I sold the 94 Z28 to a guy in Hawaii of all places. He had to have it trucked to CA and then shipped to Ouahu from there. I only drove it a few times last year. I fish almost every night after work and on weekends (except when working on black Camaro above) and it sucked on gas and fishing gear capacity. Plus, since I have become a fishing addict, I no longer spent nights and weekends at cruises or cruising in general. 
 The black Camaro has been in the works for the better part of the last 3 years. We didn't start working on it intensely until late spring, homever. 
 It is street legal. It has a license plate that reads "BYE401K". My son's doing. I don't expect it to see much street time, though. C16 is about $11/gallon and it isn't exactly a fuel-efficient ride. ;) 
 

 Thank you - Ford trucks have always been my life. I was 13 - summer of 68 - when I used a farmers tractor to pull home my first one with a V tow bar, all by myself early one Sunday morning - a 48 F-1. :) When I turned 16 it was ready to go!

 
 We're looking for a F250 to use as a tow vehicle. I'd love to get the turbo-diesel, but we'll take what we can find that reasonably priced. I prefer Ford trucks, too.
We just installed an AMS-1000 boost controller and took the car to the track on Saturday. When we have all of the bugs worked out of it, it'll be quicker than we even imagined. emoticon_xgood
Would a youtube vid of er going down the track be possible? emoticon_xbouncer

Would a youtube vid of er going down the track be possible? emoticon_xbouncer

 
 It's not a youtube video. It's from Streetfire. Note the delay after the green light comes on. My son was trying to build boost on the starting line. That's why we got the AMS-1000. It's a boost controller.
 
 LTLHOMER first passes at Milan - Car Videos on StreetFire
 
 I found a video of my son's prior ride, a 94Z24 with twin turbos. You'll see a small puff of smoke followed by billowing smoke as the engine sent a connecting rod through the oil pan at over 150mph. Notice, even after blowing the engine up 300' before the finish line, he still made a 9 second run. 
 http://videos.streetfire.net/video/TwinTurbo-94-z28-Boom_168045.htm

 Really nice. 
 
 If I remember right, the changeover from class racing to bracket racing was pretty abrupt in the mid seventies. Naturally, so was the changeover from 4-speeds to automatics, for better consistency. But after watching that vid, I find myself wondering if automatics wouldn't have taken over anyway, even if consistency wasn't a factor. They seem to have the technology today to make those autos lock up and pull strong all the way through, with a minimum of slippage. Maybe it's always been that way for the fast cars - 9 seconds or faster, I don't know. Even in the early seventies, I don't remember seeing the rail jobs on television catching gears. :p
 
 
 
I found a video of my son's prior ride, a 94Z24 with twin turbos. You'll see a small puff of smoke followed by billowing smoke as the engine sent a connecting rod through the oil pan at over 150mph. Notice, even after blowing the engine up 300' before the finish line, he still made a 9 second run. 
 Twin-Turbo 94 z28 Boom - Car Videos on StreetFire

 
 Somebody said a wordy dird. 
 
 I did nothing but body work all through the 80's. I shouldn't admit this - one of my first jobs was my younger brothers 67 Mustang with a 289. Paint job, with the addition of a big plastic box scoop on the hood. Per the instructions with the scoop, I bonded it to the hood with epoxy resin. The instructions didn't say anything about backing it up with bolts, darn it. After 4 or 5 years, he was at Thorn Hill, kinda faded by then - some cracks around the scoop. Just as he was crossing the line (it was a high 13 second car/ about 100 mph) and that scoop let go! I wasn't there, but he told me it must have gone 100 feet in the air. Thorn Hill management was, uh, not amused. emoticon_xangel

Really nice. 
 
 If I remember right, the changeover from class racing to bracket racing was pretty abrupt in the mid seventies. Naturally, so was the changeover from 4-speeds to automatics, for better consistency. But after watching that vid, I find myself wondering if automatics wouldn't have taken over anyway, even if consistency wasn't a factor. They seem to have the technology today to make those autos lock up and pull strong all the way through, with a minimum of slippage. Maybe it's always been that way for the fast cars - 9 seconds or faster, I don't know. Even in the early seventies, I don't remember seeing the rail jobs on television catching gears. :p
 

 Top Fuelers don't use any transmissions. Thery use centrifugal clutches that engage at various times providing less and less slip.
 Most other cars use some sort of automatic, either clutchless or with a clutch for starting line. 
 Automatics have an advantage of multiplying torque at the starting line. The disadvantage is their power loss which can be 20% with some trannies.

 Losing a scoop isn't so bad. Losing 8 quarts of oil is a disaster.
